text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Deputy Prime Minister Tansu Ciller bargains with Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan on taking over his office in June.
- The Islamist-led government appoints the general manager of state-owned petroluem refinery Tupras in what is seen as a step to put their supporters in key posts.
- Erbakan's Welfare Party is angered by a prosecutor's legal challenge to close down the party. Islamist State Minister Abdullah Gul says they will take legal action against the prosecutor.
- Deputies who made a U-turn ahead of a parliamentary vote to topple the government say they regret taking the government's side.
- The Finance Ministry stops the monthly announcement of data after reports that the government's balanced budget plans were hit by a deficit in March.
- Turkish armed forces move to Mosul -- near Saddam Hussein's Iraqi forces -- in a cross-border operation against Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels.
- McDonnell Douglas proposes the manufacture of MD-90 passenger planes in Turkey.
- The cabinet meeting is postponed once again. The cabinet has not met for seven weeks.
- The leather sector hopes to sell out their stock in summer sales to holidaymakers.
- The Foreign Ministry says a regulation on the sharing of international water produced by the United Nation does not bind Turkey.
- A Turkish delegation of businessmen, lecturers and journalists visit Turkish enterprises in Turkmenistan.
